Second-generation refrigerants (HCFCs) are strictly limited due to their harmful effects on the ozone layer. These harmful halogenated hydrocarbons can be converted to perfluoroalkanes through the hydrodehalogenation reaction, which can be used as an alternative to HCFCs with a low ozone depletion potential (ODP), and contribute to reducing environmental impact. Metal-modified (e.g. Ni, Pd, Pt, etc.) activated carbon catalysts are widely used in hydrodehalogenation reactions. In contrast, activated carbon has a complex composition and pore structure, and the morphology and structure are difficult to regulate. In this study, we propose a treatment approach to evaluate the impact of the Ni/C catalysts on the HCFC-124 (R124) hydrodehalogenation performance. To achieve this, we subjected the parent activated carbon (CP) to three distinct treatments: fluorine treatment (CF), alkali treatment (COH) and acid treatment (CH). These treatments dissolve the ash and benefit to modify the pore structure and have different chemical properties of the activated carbon. The R124 hydrodehalogenation reaction on nickel-impregnated carbon catalysts at 623 K was carried out. Interestingly, the presence of acidic sites in catalysts benefits the reaction. Further, we revealed the mathematical relationship between the acidic sites and the initial conversion and average selectivity. Moreover, we found that the existence of defects induced coke deposition at defective sites rather than acidic sites and only generated soft coke, which typically served as a "spectator". The new strategy improved the performance of Ni/C catalysts for catalytic hydrodehalogenation reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni/C Fluoride Acid sites Defects Hydrodehalogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the improvement of environmental awareness and the development of green chemistry, the second-generation refrigerants (HCFCs) allowances first target the members with the highest ozone depletion potential (ODP), like HCFC-22 (CClF2, chlorodifluoromethane), HCFC-141b (CH3CCl2F, 1,1-dichloro-1-fluoroethane), HCFC-142b (CH3CClF2, 1‑chloro-1,1-difluoroethane), HCFC-124 (CHF2CClF2, 1‑chloro-1,2,2,2-tetrachloroethane), etc. [1–5] Their production or import as refrigerants has been banned since 2020 (10 years in advance of the total HCFCs ban in 2030) and completely phased out by 2040 due to their behavior in the atmosphere: the higher the number of chlorine atoms, the more Cl free radicals can be formed, and thus the higher the ODP value [1]. With the continued interest in developing zero ODP models, the replacement of all CCl bonds by CH bonds led to the emergence of third-generation hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) [1], such as HFC-134a (CF3CH2F, 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane) becoming one of the most popular fluorocarbons in the refrigerants field [6,7]. When converting to third-generation fluorine-containing refrigerants by using second-generation refrigerants as feedstock is regarded as an ideal route, the damage to the ozone layer can be reduced greatly with the low cost and high economic benefits [5]. During the dehalogenation process, fluorine atoms are more electronegative and bind more stably to carbon atoms than other halogen atoms [8,9]. Compared with dehalogenation reactions, hydrodehalogenation reactions tend to prefer replacing halogen atoms (e.g., chlorine atoms) that have smaller electronegativity and less stable bonding with carbon atoms [10], so the hydrodehalogenation reaction as a clean and efficient reaction method have received much attention and research over the last decades [10,11]. However, during the hydrodehalogenation reaction, the catalyst is easily poisoned by the HX (such as, HCl and HF) generated from the reaction, leading to catalyst deactivation [5,12–14]. Therefore, hydrodehalogenation catalysts, especially for catalyst supports, could be highly stable in corrosive environments and avoid the occurrence of negative reactions leading to loss of catalyst selectivity. Among the catalyst supports, activated carbon is an exceptional material including a high degree of porosity and surface area [15], and it has excellent corrosion resistance to HX [15], which is frequently used as the catalyst support for catalytic hydrodehalogenation reaction [16–19]. However, the carbon supports have a complex surface and pore structure, which makes it difficult to regulate the morphology and properties during the catalyst preparation process. Different ways of catalyst improvement have been reported [15], such as physical activation (including nitrogen [20], steam [21], CO2 [22], etc.), redox activation [23,24], and chemical activation (mainly including acid [25] and alkali activation [26]). The latter represents an extensive research topic for carbon activation since its low required activation temperature, short activation time, low energy consumption, and high yield of prepared activated carbon, which makes it easy to accurately regulate the pore structure and surface properties of activated carbon [27]. However, traditional acid or alkali activation shows selectivity for the dissolution of ash and is difficult to remove simultaneously. On the other hand, in our previous studies [28–33], we found that fluorine treatment was able to dissolve unstable structural units without selectivity different from alkali or acid treatments, so we further applied this conclusion to the carbon supports. Although the chemical activation of activated carbon has been deeply researched, current chemical methods are still selective for ash dissolution. In this study, we creatively used fluoride to treat activated carbon and compared it with alkali-treated or acid-treated activated carbon. Subsequently, the morphology and chemical properties were characterized and their catalytic performance in R124 hydrodehalogenation was evaluated. Moreover, we established the relationship between acidic sites and reaction activity and explored the role of defective sites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Parent carbon (C, Flake, denoted as CP) obtained from Sinochem Lantian Co., Ltd. The reagents used for the treatment of parent carbon are Deionized water, Ammonium fluoride (NH4F, AR), Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, Flake, AR), Nitric acid (HNO3, AR), Nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O, AR). All chemicals were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Corporation and used directly without further purification. 2.2 Treatment of parent carbon 2.2.1 NH4F etching The fluoride etching of CP was carried out in NH4F solution (40 wt.%) at 343 K for 0.5 h under stirring with a solid/liquid ratio of 1:30. The product was separated by pumping filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried at 353 K overnight. This sample was denoted as CF. 2.2.2 NaOH leaching The alkaline leaching of CP was carried out in NaOH solution (0.2 mol·L-1) at 343 K for 1 h under stirring with a solid/liquid ratio of 1:30. The product was separated by pumping filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried at 353 K overnight. This sample was denoted as COH. 2.2.3 HNO3 leaching The HNO3 treatment of CP was carried out in HNO3 solution (0.2 mol·L-1) at 343 K for 1 h under stirring with a solid/liquid ratio of 1:30. The product was separated by pumping filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried at 353 K overnight. This sample was denoted as CH. 2.3 The impregnation of nickel The parent (CP) and treated samples (CF, COH and CH) were wet-impregnated with nickel. 5 g of the sample was mixed with an aqueous solution containing 0.6 g of NiCl2·6H2O and 20 mL of deionized water under stirring for 3 h Then, the samples were dried overnight and calcined at 575 K in static air for 3 h with a ramp of 5 K min-1. The nickel impregnated samples were denoted as Ni/CP, Ni/CF, Ni/COH and Ni/CH. 2.4 Characterization The ash composition after calcination at 1073 K with 5 K·min-1 ramp rate and Ni loading content were analyzed by using a 7900 ICP-MS (Agilent Technologies). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of parent and post-treated samples were collected from 10 to 80° on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with Cu and Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The voltage is 40 kV. The scanning speed is 2°·min-1. The porosity properties of samples were analyzed on a BSD-660S (Beishide) instrument at 77 K. Before the measurement, the samples were degassed at 573 K in vacuum for 4 h The pore size distributions (PSD) were obtained by using the H-K (Original) model applied to the adsorption branch of the isotherms. The specific surface area was determined from the BET equation, and the micropore volume and pore size distribution determined by H-K (Original) method and external surface area from the t-plot method. The structural properties were analyzed on a Thermo Fischer DXR (Thermo Fisher Scientific) with the 514 nm laser excitation from 50 to 4000 cm-1. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was performed on the NEXUS 670 (Nicolet) spectrometer at 4 cm-1 optical resolution from 400 to 4000 cm-1. The peaks were integrated based on the parent carbon (CP). The size and morphology of the samples were measured with a Sigma 300 (ZEISS) scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with a field emission gun. The acceleration voltage and work distance were 3 kV and 6 mm respectively. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken with a FEI Talos F200S (Thermo Fisher Scientific) with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of NH3 was measured in a quartz reactor using 100 mg samples. Each catalyst was first pretreated using He (200 mL min-1) at 573 K for 1 h and then cooled to 303 K for the NH3-TPD analysis. The sample was saturated with the gas to be tested (NH3/He) for 1 h and purged with He to remove physically adsorbed species for 1.5 h, then desorption was carried out at a temperature increase rate of 5 K·min-1 up to 1073 K. The peaks were integrated based on the parent carbon (CP). The gas concentrations were measured using the TP-5080D (Tianjin Xianquan Industry and Trade Development Co., Ltd). Spent catalysts were thermogravimetric analysis for coke content and composition by using a TGA/DSC 3+/1100LF (Mettler Toledo). 2.5 Catalytic test The catalytic performance of the hydrodehalogenation reaction of Ni/C catalysts was evaluated by the fixed-bed microreactor (VDRT-200SMT, Quzhou Vodo Instryment Co., Ltd) at ambient pressure and 623 K. The samples were crushed, sieved and the 10–20 mesh fraction was retained for catalytic evaluation. 0.3 g catalyst was packed (on top of the quartz wool layers) in the middle of a transparent quartz tube (380 mm long and 8 mm of internal diameter). Before the reaction, the reaction tube was heated from room temperature to 673 K (ramp rate of 5 K·min-1) with 20 mL min-1 of H2 and N2 flow respectively for 2 h, then when cooled to reaction temperature (623 K), the gas flow was switched to 16 mL min-1 R124 and 35 mL min-1 H2 flow to conduct the hydrodehalogenation reaction. The products were passed through a NaOH solution and water to trap acid gases and then analyzed offline by the gas chromatograph with FID. Calculated the conversion of methane and the selectivity of the main products and the average conversion and selectivity by integration during the reaction. The reacted samples were named as: ANi/CP, ANi/CF, ANi/COH and ANi/CH. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The NH4F treatment (CF) The NH4F treatment resulted in the lowest ash content and showed effective dissolution of all ash components without selectivity, especially for the S species (Table S1). Different morphology from the parent carbon (Fig. 1 a, b), the clear etched morphology and rich pore structures in the CF sample can be directly observed (Fig. 1c, d), and exhibited better adsorption capacity than the parent carbon (Fig. 2 a). The micropore volume of the CF sample reached 0.63 cm3·g-1, indicating the high quality of the microporosity of this sample compared to the parent carbon (Fig. 2b, Table 1 ). Specially, the graphitized structure almost disappeared completely after fluorine treatment as testified by X-ray diffraction (Fig. 2c) [34]. Meanwhile, in Raman spectra, the d-band at 1350 cm-1 is dominated by edges, defects and disordered sites, and the G-band at 1580 cm-1 is dominated by planar telescopic vibrations of sp2-C atomic pairs [35]. Hence, the ratio of the intensity of the d-band to the G-band (ID/IG ratio) usually indicates the degree of defects in carbon materials [36], the CF sample had the highest disorder level (Fig. 2d) in these samples. This indicated that the fluorine treatment could maximize the introduction of disorder structure (defects) by the destruction of the graphitized structure. The chemical properties of activated carbon surface are mainly determined by the category and quantity of surface functional groups, which are mostly oxygen-containing functional groups such as carboxyl group (-COOH), hydroxyl group (-OH) and carbonyl group (-C = O) [37]. Among them, the strong adsorption bands in the waveband of 3600–3200 cm-1 were ascribed to OH stretching vibrations, implying the existence of carboxylic, hydroxyl and chemisorbed water [38].; the bonds in the range of 1740–1480 cm-1 were assigned to C = C or C = O stretching vibrations [38,39]; and the bands in the range of 1300–1000 cm-1 were ascribed to CO or CO-C stretching vibrations [38,40] (Fig. 2e). Compared with the parent carbon, the peak intensity for stretching vibration of C = C at 1638 cm-1 and CO or CO-C near 1610 cm-1 were weakened in the CF sample (Table S2). In consideration of the (002) and (100) diffraction peaks declining apparently shown in Fig. 2c as well as the weakening of the C = C and CO or CO-C bonds strength, indicating that the process of fluorine treatment hardly introduced surface oxygen-containing functional groups (e.g. -OH, -COOH, etc.), just by the destruction of the graphitized structure leading to the C = C and CO or CO-C bonds broken [41] and removal of ash (Table S1) to create the secondary pore structure, meanwhile exposed more weakly acidic sites in the CF sample than others (Fig. 2f) as determined by NH3-TPD (Figure S1). NH4F etching is a unique chemical treatment that is expected to remove ash unbiased from active carbon. In our previous research [42,43], when an element-biased etching behavior was observed, the apparent “desilication” [42] or “dealumination” [43] phenomena were previously attributed to the extrinsic [42] or intrinsic [43] properties related to architecture characteristics. 3.2 The NaOH treatment (COH) The parent carbon after NaOH leaching (COH) also observed rough external surface from the TEM images (Fig. 1e, f) and also showed a rich pore structure with the highest microporous pore volume (0.69 cm3·g-1) (Fig. 2a, b; Table 1). However, it is worth noting that during the process seems to be different from the fluorine etching, COH had a much higher specific surface area (around 1.7 times than parent carbon, Table 1) and lower crystallinity than CP (Fig. 1c). Interestingly, different from the fluoride treatment, alkali treatment seemed to be selective for ash dissolution and more beneficial for the removal of Si rather than S, Al and other species (Table S1). During the NaOH leaching, selective dissolution or etching along the boundaries, intergrowths, and defects within each particle [33], as well as destroying part of the graphitized structure (Fig. 1c), with a slight increase in defect content compared to the parent carbon (Fig. 1d). In addition, the acid content decreased significantly after alkali treatment, especially for the weak acidic sites, which are only 4 % compared to the parent carbon (Fig. 1f). Alkaline activation of activated carbon not only improves porosity and specific surface area, but also introduces alkaline nitrogen and oxygen groups on the activated carbon surface (such as -OH, Fig. 1e, Table S2), while it has been shown that the adsorption capacity of activated carbon can be effectively enhanced [44]. 3.3 The HNO3 treatment (CH) The post-treatment of the parent carbon in acidic media also resulted in a rich pore structure and external surface area (Fig. 1g, h, Fig. 2a, b and Table 1) while preserving the high crystallinity and graphite-type structure ((002) and (100) facets, Fig. 2c), thus the introduction of defect sites was limited (Fig. 2d). Similar to the alkali treatment, it was beneficial to dissolve Al, Si in the ash, but the ash content was also higher than the CF sample (Table S1). In addition, both CF and CH samples keep more acidic sites than CP, especially for the strongly acidic sites (Fig. 2f). At a suitable temperature, the acid oxidant can enrich the internal pores of activated carbon, improve its pore size and unclog the blocked areas. HNO3 is a commonly used oxidant, making the activated carbon to obtain more acidic sites (Fig. 2f) and oxidation groups on the surface (Fig. 2e, Table S2) than other acid reagents [26]. Based on these post-treatment processes, the surface spherical particles of the parent carbon have all disappeared (Figure S2). SEM-Mapping confirmed that its main composition is C and little Si species (Figure S3), and all the samples showed obvious etched traces (Fig. 1, Figure S2). In summary, we designed a series of activated carbons with similar specific surface area (∼1600 m2·g-1) and microporous pore volume (∼0.65 ml·g-1), with different acidic sites and defect contents. 3.4 Ni-impregnated activated carbon samples: Ni/CP, Ni/CF, Ni/COH, Ni/CH In this work, we used the excess volume impregnation method to load the above samples with 5 % Ni species (The actual load is about 4.2 % by ICP). Figure S4 showed the XRD patterns of the carbon loaded with Ni and maintained similar crystallinity with the carbon support. There were no characteristic peaks identified in the diffractograms around 37.4° and 43.2° that could be attributed to the Ni oxide phases, indicating that Ni species were highly dispersed (or presented as small clusters) in activated carbons [45]. In addition, after loading Ni, the specific surface area, micropore volume and mesopore volume were decreased (Figure S5, Table S3). Ni species migrated into the pore channels, especially for microporous (Table S3) and still maintain high thermal stability (Figure S6). After the introduction of the Ni species, the evolution of the defective sites was confirmed by the Raman studies. All the Raman spectra also showed the d-band and G-bond regions (Figure S7a). In comparison to before loaded Ni, the ratios of ID/IG slightly decreased in all samples (Figure S7b), indicated the fraction of Ni species can be connected to non-graphitic phase structures (such as defects, and edge sites) which presents a high potential for the introduction of high dispersion metal species in carbon [46]. On the other hand, the number of acid sites decreased as measured by NH3-TPD (Figure S8), especially for strong and medium-strong acidic sites have almost disappeared, which was the main driver of Ni migration into the pore channels and replaced the acidic protons [47]. As can be seen from the SEM images (Fig. 3 ), there are still a large number of spherical particles on the parent carbon surface after loading with Ni species, the same can be seen in the CP sample, which were identified by Mapping spot scanning as small spheres containing mainly C, O, and Si, and also showed etching traces after treatment (Fig. 3), which have similar characteristics to those before loading with Ni species (Fig. 1). In the EDS-Mapping images, all the samples contained mainly C, O, and Ni species (Fig. 3), and the Ni species were uniformly dispersed on the surface of the Ni/C samples (Fig. 3), the Ni species could be dispersed uniformly on the surface of the catalysts by the wet-impregnation. The distribution of Ni species was further characterized by TEM (Fig. 4 ). The etched mesoporous structure was also observed in all treated carbons. In addition, no agglomerated Ni species were observed, in agreement with the XRD results. The Ni species were all uniformly dispersed on the carbon (Ni particle size around 2 nm, Figure S9), and the content did not differ much from the loading (∼4 %). Specially, the content of Ni species was further compared by EDS surface scanning of mesoporous structure (Ni/CF, Fig. 4), and it can be seen that the Ni species had a concentration gradient near the catalyst pore (Figure S10a). As the distance decreased towards the pore, the concentration of Ni species gradually increased (Figure S10b). Notably, this region also coincided with the area of higher defect density, where the Ni content was higher compared to other regions. This observation is consistent with the Raman results (Figure S7). However, the content of Ni species in the pore channel showed a decreasing trend (Figure S10b), which is also consistent with previous research results on the dispersion of metal species by defect engineering [33]. The defects can interact with the metal species, so a part of the Ni species is enriched around the pore. 3.5 Catalytic evaluation of Ni/C catalysts in the hydrodehalogenation reaction The hydrodehalogenation reaction performance of the parent (Ni/CP) and treated samples (Ni/CF, Ni/COH, Ni/CH) with time on the stream was carried out. The catalyst activation temperature was 673 K, then cooled down to 623 K to carry out the reaction at atmospheric pressure and a high GHSV of 10,000 ml/(gcat·h). Interestingly, the catalyst just a pure carbon carrier or Ni exhibited poor reactivity (Figure S10), indicating that the presence of acidic sites and nickel species in the catalyst benefits this reaction. For Ni/C catalysts, all the R124 (CHF2CClF2, 1‑chloro-1,2,2,2-tetrachloroethane) conversions followed the deactivated transition state (Fig. 5 a). As the reaction proceeded, the selectivity of the dechlorination product R134a (CF3CH2F, 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane) and the selectivity of the defluorination product R143a (CH3CF3, 1,1,1-trifluoroethane) continuously decreased (Fig. 5b, 5c), and under the high temperature the dehydrofluorination product gradually dominated, resulting in increased VDF (CH2 CF2, vinylidene fluoride) selectivity (Fig. 5d). After fluorine or acid treatment showed higher conversions than Ni/CP and Ni/COH samples, attributed to the more weak acidic sites and thus provided more active sites for C-X bond activation than CP and COH. Therefore, the content of weak acidic sites showed a good linear relationship with the average conversion of R124 in the dehydrofluorination reaction under similar Ni loading (Fig. 6 a). In addition, the selectivity of R134a and VDF was also related to the acidic sites in a quadratic manner (Fig. 6b), with more acidic sites beneficial to the R134a dehydrogenation reaction to produce VDF, while the intermediate product R143a selectivity remained stable. Furthermore, Ni/CF had better stability related to its more defective sites than Ni/CH will be discussed later. Specially, the Ni/COH exhibited a very low conversion rate, while did not exhibit a deactivation pattern. The alkali treatment lost too many acidic sites, resulting in difficulty in activating the C-X bond and low conversion similar to pure Ni catalyst at 673 K (Figure S11). These will be further explained in the SEM mapping images below (Figure S12, Figure S13). In summary, the fluorine treatment has more weak acidic sites and defective sites with the highest average conversion and catalytic efficiency than others (Table S4). 3.6 Spent catalyst The pore structure of the post-reaction Ni/C catalysts was analyzed as shown in Fig. 7 , after the reaction, the nitrogen adsorption, specific surface area and pore volume all showed a significant decrease in nitrogen adsorption characteristic (Figure S5, Table S3), and the coke was mainly distributed in the microporous pore (Fig. 7a, Table S3). Specially, for the Ni/CF sample, nitrogen sorption and microporous pore volume were the lowest than others (Figure S5, Table S3), thus the defective sites were able to promote coke deposition [33], especially in the microporous pores. Further, combined with pore structure analysis, TG analysis was conducted on the coke content and distribution after the reaction (Fig. 7b). Among them, the Ni/COH catalyst had the highest coke content, reaching 20 % (Fig. 7b, Figure S14) and the coke decomposition temperature shifted toward high temperatures (Fig. 7b), and it corresponded to the lowest conversion (Fig. 5a). Therefore, under the similar pore structure (Table S3), Ni species loading and dispersion (Fig. 3, 4), the absence of acid sites (Fig. 6a) was detrimental to the hydrodehalogenation reaction (Fig. 5a), resulting in further coking at active sites, primarily in hard coke (Fig. 7b). Therefore, the Ni/COH catalyst with seldom acidic sites (Fig. 6a) could be used as a reference catalyst, as it maintained a low conversion during the reaction (Fig. 5a). Compared to the reference catalyst (Ni/COH), the Ni/CP, Ni/CF, and Ni/CH catalysts all exhibited catalyst deactivation modes (Fig. 5a). As the reaction was carried out, the active sites were continuously covered by coke, combined with the relationship between the acidic site and reaction activity (Fig. 6a), the conversion of the Ni/CP, Ni/CF, and Ni/CH catalysts decreased to around 4 % finally, which was similar to the conversion of Ni/COH catalyst as shown in Fig. 5a. Specifically, the Ni/CH catalyst exhibited poor stability (Fig. 5a), which was mainly attributed to containing more acidic sites than others, particularly including some strong acidic sites (Figure S8). Additionally, the catalysts' stability decreased as the number of acidic sites increased. However, the Ni/CF has a similar content of acidic sites as Ni/CH (Fig. 6a), but it contains more defective sites (Figure S7), which can induce the preferential deposition of coke at defective sites and lead to more soft coke than ANi/CH (Fig. 7b). Finally, after the acidic sites were covered and caused the catalyst deactivation [48], all catalysts reached similar conversions (∼4 %, Fig. 5a). Therefore, under a similar acidic site, the introduction of defects (Ni/CF) induced coke deposition at defective sites rather than acidic sites and only generated soft coke, which typically served as a "spectator" in the hydrodehalogenation reaction to improve the stability (better than Ni/CH), which is also consistent with our previous research results [33]. The spent catalysts were further characterized by SEM (Figure S12) and TEM (Fig. 8 ). As can be seen from the SEM images (Figure S12), all of them had small particles with bright spots, and the EDS surface scanning identified that mainly contained C, O, Ni and F, Cl elements (Figure S12), as the aggregated Ni species after the reaction, and proved that Ni was the active species for this reaction. Interestingly, carbon nanotube structures were produced on the catalyst surface after the reaction, especially for the fluorine-treated sample (Figure S12b). Specially, for the Ni/COH catalyst, the surface contained a relatively high amount of Cl elements (Figure S13), and corresponded to a low conversion rate, indicating that the chlorine-containing R124 adsorbed and further agglomerated to form coke attributed to the lack of acidic sites, rather than effectively carrying out dehalogenation reaction and diffusing out. The reacted Ni/C catalysts were further characterized by TEM, as shown in Fig. 8, the F and Cl elements and the agglomeration of Ni species were also observed in all samples after the reaction. Specially, for the acid-treated sample, the aggregated Ni species still exhibited a high dispersibility of the spent Ni/CH catalyst (Figure S15), related to the acid-treated support being rich in medium-strong and strong acidic sites (Figure S8), and Ni preferentially interacted with strong acidic sites, leading to a strong interaction between the active Ni species and the acid-treated support [47]. However, as the reaction proceeded, the formation of coke deposited on the active sites continuously, while the lack of defective sites, resulted in coke deposited over the active sites and poor stability of the acid-treated catalyst. Consequently, for the hydrodehalogenation reaction, the formation of coke deposited accelerated the deactivation of the catalyst, especially the coke deposited on the acidic sites, followed by the agglomeration of active species. 4 Conclusions After the carbon supports were treated with fluorine, alkali and acid, these treatments dissolve the ash of the parent carbon sample and the total ash content is in the order: CF<COH<CH<CP. Different from the conventional acid and alkali treatments, the fluorine treatment can dissolve ash species without selectivity, almost destroy the graphitized structure and increase the degree of disorder to produce many defective sites, and expose weakly acidic sites, but not change the chemistry of the surface groups. The catalytic test of the four catalysts in the hydrodehalogenation reaction, the fluorine-treated carbon support exhibited the highest catalytic efficiency, and we established a mathematical relationship between the acidic sites and the initial conversion and average selectivity. In addition, we found that coke was mainly deposited in micropores. In this reaction, catalyst deactivation is mainly caused by the coke deposition on the acidic sites, followed by the active phase agglomeration. The fluorine-treated catalyst (Ni/CF) exhibited the highest activity compared to the others, and coke was deposited preferentially at defective sites rather than acidic sites. Additionally, the extra soft coke generated merely served as a “spectator” in the hydrodehalogenation reaction. coredata.dc:description: Second-generation refrigerants (HCFCs) are strictly limited due to their harmful effects on the ozone layer. These harmful halogenated hydrocarbons can be converted to perfluoroalkanes through the hydrodehalogenation reaction, which can be used as an alternative to HCFCs with a low ozone depletion potential (ODP), and contribute to reducing environmental impact. Metal-modified (e.g. Ni, Pd, Pt, etc.) activated carbon catalysts are widely used in hydrodehalogenation reactions. In contrast, activated carbon has a complex composition and pore structure, and the morphology and structure are difficult to regulate. In this study, we propose a treatment approach to evaluate the impact of the Ni/C catalysts on the HCFC-124 (R124) hydrodehalogenation performance. To achieve this, we subjected the parent activated carbon (CP) to three distinct treatments: fluorine treatment (CF), alkali treatment (COH) and acid treatment (CH). These treatments dissolve the ash and benefit to modify the pore structure and have different chemical properties of the activated carbon. The R124 hydrodehalogenation reaction on nickel-impregnated carbon catalysts at 623 K was carried out. Interestingly, the presence of acidic sites in catalysts benefits the reaction. Further, we revealed the mathematical relationship between the acidic sites and the initial conversion and average selectivity. Moreover, we found that the existence of defects induced coke deposition at defective sites rather than acidic sites and only generated soft coke, which typically served as a "spectator". The new strategy improved the performance of Ni/C catalysts for catalytic hydrodehalogenation reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Construction of acid functions and defective sites on Carbon supported Ni for HCFC-124 Hydrodehalogenation
